metadata.case_name: Raghutilaka Tirtha Sripadangalavaru Swamiji v. State of Mysore

facts.text: Appellant owns 6 acres and 30 ghuntas of garden land in village Mulbagilu in Taluka Thirthahalli in the district of Shimoga.

Respondent No. 3, Ramappa Gowda, is tenant of the appellant's land. A registered lease deed executed on March 11, 1943, under which respondent No. 3 undertook to pay 82-1/2 maunds of areca in addition to Rs. 17/12 in cash as rent per year.

In 1955, respondent No. 3 filed an application before respondent No. 2, the Tehsildar of Thirthahalli, under section 12 of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952, claiming fixation of standard rent (Tenancy case 85 of 1955-56).

Respondent No. 1, Government of Mysore, issued Notification No. R9. 10720/L.S. 73-54-2 on March 28/29, 1955, under s. 6 of the Act, fixing standard rent for lands of the category to which appellant's land belongs at one third of the produce.

Appellant filed writ petition in Mysore High Court on December 16, 1955, challenging validity of s. 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952, and the notification issued under it dated March 31, 1952 (earlier mention, but context 1955).
Mysore High Court rejected the contentions, held section and notification valid and constitutional.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 but refused under Art. 132. Appellant obtained permission from Supreme Court to raise constitutional interpretation question.
Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 passed to regulate relations of landlords and tenants of agricultural lands, impose restrictions on transfers, provide relief to agricultural tenants.

Notification under s.6(2) fixes maximum rent at one-third for Schedule I (Maidan areas) and one-fourth for Schedule II (Malanad areas) with effect from April 1, 1955. Maidan lands on plains, Malanad on hilly tracts, differing in rainfall, cultivation, living conditions, labour, produce.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 6(2) of the Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and the notification issued under it infringe Arts. 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31 and 31A of the Constitution.
Whether the notification under s.6(2) is invalid as inconsistent with s.6(1), with exception swallowing the general rule.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned s.6(2) and notification infringe fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19(1)(f), 26, 31, 31A.
Preamble of Mysore Act differs from Bombay Act, no reference to social justice or efficient land use.
Unlike Bombay Act, no distinction between irrigated and non-irrigated lands in fixing maximum rent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6(1) Mysore Act vs. Bombay Tenancy Act s.6(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Absence of minimum rent provision unlike Bombay Act.
Notification inconsistent with s.6(1), exception cannot swallow general rule (Macbeth v. Ashley).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.6(1) and s.6(2) Mysore Act; Macbeth v. Ashley (1874) L.R. 2 Sc. App. 352

court_reasoning.text: Validity of s.6 upheld as substantially similar to s.6 Bombay Tenancy Act upheld in Vasantal case; reasons apply equally.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions resemble Bombay Act modelled on.

court_reasoning.text: Preamble difference immaterial; Act's scheme shows policy of social justice for agrarian reform, improving tenants' conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Social justice writ large on face of Act.

court_reasoning.text: No essential need for irrigated/non-irrigated distinction in prescribing maximum ceiling; prescribes maximum, not minimum.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixation of maximum ceiling not requiring classification.

court_reasoning.text: Absence of minimum rent does not introduce infirmity; no reliance on minimum in Vasantal decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minimum fixed post High Court decision in Vasantal.

court_reasoning.text: s.6(2) independent provision, not proviso/exception to s.6(1); both coordinate, s.6(1) general ceiling, s.6(2) empowers lower rates by area/other basis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification does not amend s.6(1); can cover all areas.

court_reasoning.text: Classification into Maidan and Malanad lands reasonable, based on rainfall, cultivation, conditions, labour, produce.
Macbeth distinguished; not evasion, bona fide exercise; s.6 not general rule + exception structure.

holdings.text: s.6 of Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 is valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Upholds validity of s.6 Bombay Tenancy Act; reasons apply to Mysore s.6.
Exception cannot swallow rule, but inapplicable to s.6 structure; involved evasion of statute.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates tenancy, fixes maximum rent at 1/2 crop, empowers govt to fix lower; scheme for tenant relief.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged on grounds of infringement; certificate and permission under 132/133.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Mysore High Court decision; declares s.6(2) of Mysore Tenancy Act, 1952 and notification under it valid and constitutional; challenge covered by Vasantal precedent; notification independent power reasonably exercised.

key_quotes.text: "the policy of social justice can be safely said to be writ large on the face of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "if the exception is to swallow up the rule it ceases, of course, to be an exception at all"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Macbeth but distinguishes as inapplicable to s.6.

key_quotes.text: "Sub-section (2) is so worded that in terms it cannot be said to be a proviso to sub-s. (1) and in substance it is not such a proviso nor is it an exception to sub-s. (1)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
